title: Where does the phrase 'the student has become the master' come from? - Quora
tags: Etymology of English Phrases (Origin or History of English Phrases)

response.answer_text: This is one of those tricky phrases that has been recycled many times during the course of history, which as a result only serves to further obscure its true origins. The reason being that the proverb “takes on a life of its own” and becomes a kind of myth or folklore in itself. Eg: I read it here… This author wrote it… This movie character said it… It was on this movie… This Philosopher first quoted it… It actually comes from this culture…. etc… In this case I'm not really sure that “the student has become the master”, is actually a direct representation of an original quote. Rather its possible that it is an interpretive conclusion to a proverb found in the 4th century traditional Chinese text, Tao Te Ching, which was reputedly authored by the Chinese Philosopher Lao Tzu. (Tao Te Ching, along with Zhuanghzi, another Traditional Chinese text, is considered to be the foundational texts for both religious and philosophical Taoism. Although the actual author and dating of these texts are still widely debated.) The original credited quote is interperted as follows: “When the student is ready the teacher will appear. When the student is truly ready... The teacher will Disappear.” The implication being that at the conclusion of the lessons, the teacher will have imparted the entirety of his knowledge to the student. Therefore the student no longer requires a teacher, but can continue to learn independently. Perhaps even one day becoming more knowledgeable than the teacher himself. (Some transcriptions of this quote replace “Student” with “Pupil”, whilst others replace “Teacher” with “Master” and vice versa). Perhaps this might be a potential source. However it should be noted that the text wasn't translated into English until 1868, an estimated 2000 to 2200 years later, therefore there could be quite a lot of meaning lost in translation. Other possible notable variations (although I'm sure there could be many more) include: “Poor is the pupil who does not surpass his master”. Leonardo Da Vinci. “It is the greatest achievement of a teacher to enable his students to surpass him”. John G. Kemeny. “It is commonly said that a teacher fails if he has not been surpassed by his students”. Edmond H. Fischer. Not forgetting more popular culture references: “Now I am the Master”. Darth Vader. “It's evolution man. One day the student becomes the teacher”. Big Sean. Regardless of its origin “the student has become the master” is still as inspirational and relevant in modern philosophy as it was in history. Hopefully this is helpful, although I can't claim to be an expert by any means.

response.answer_text: A2A - Thank you. The origins of this concept predate the philosopher Siddhartha Gautama, more commonly referred to as Buddha (450 BCE.) He is often attributed to being the originator of the Buddhist proverb: “When the Student is ready, the teacher will appear. When the student is really ready, the teacher will disappear.” Though the accuracy of this has been debated as a Fake Buddha Quote and attributed to a much later author, Mabel Collins. However, she may have published a modern book entitled “Light on the Path” sometime prior to 1885 that contained a similar phrase, she did not conceive the concept itself. In her book the phrase was written as “For when the disciple is ready the master is ready also.” Similar constructs of this concept however have appeared in texts that can be found throughout history. In the third century, a Tibetan text by Longchen Rabjampa is noted as having “When there is a subject [student] the teacher appears.” In hermetic texts, some say originated in ancient Egypt, the same concept is presented. So, the actual origin of the full concept may be lost in antiquity and the original version may never be known for sure. The conceptual phrase is a fundamental basis of the buddhist teachings. One who seeks enlightenment is a student, one who has achieved it is a master. Of course, we could just say the origin, at least in modern terms is Anakin Skywalker or should we say Darth Vader. LOL

response.answer_text: In American mainstream culture, the concept first was introduced outside the Asian and Sinophile communities in the TV series Kung Fu. A bit orientalized and simplistic, but everything on TV is, isn’t it?  It has echoes in martial arts prior to that, and up until recent Star Wars media and discussions (Lucas based his Jedi and Sith on martial arts orders). But the root concept is deep in Asian teaching — in Hindu tradition, “Guru” is literally “light/dark” — a person who shows the difference between things to the chela or student. But the goal of the guru is for the chela to recognize non-duality, that the light and darkness are interdependent and aspects of unity. So if the guru is successful, the chela also becomes the guru. My guru from my 20s is as familiar to me as my parents’ voices when I confront a crisis. None of them are still alive. But all of them give me an excuse to be wiser than I think I am. I think, “I can’t be this smart, but what would dad or rinpoche do?” If I can “simulate” that then I am that wise, but “delegating” it protects one from egotism. In Christian tradition, we have WWJD? Who do you carry in your heart? It’s the complete assimilation of the life of virtue that ideally brings the student to grow into a teacher.

response.answer_text: This maxim is as old as our human race, so its origin is not known. But because it is a universal truth, it is often repeated and restated in books like the Bible (John 14:12) and in films like Star Wars. Human mastery of our world is built on this principle: The student strives to learn from his master. The word “study” comes from the Latin meaning “to strive”. As he continues, he becomes a disciple, one who follows his master even deeper in order to understand fully what the master understands. The word “disciple” probably comes from the Latin “dis+capere”, meaning to take apart, to analyze, in order to grasp the essence of what the master knows. Eventually, the disciple understands the core knowledge of his master and then he becomes the master and goes beyond, adding his life’s insights and teaching his own students even more than his old master knew.

response.answer_text: Thanks, James, for the A2A. This statement has probably been made countless times throughout history, wherever gifted apprentices are the students of masters. In western culture, the statement is associated particularly with Andrea del Verrocchio, an Italian painter and sculptor of the 15th century. His most famous pupil was the incomparable Leonardo da Vinci. The practice of that time was to have an apprentice work on a part of a painting that the master had undertaken; Verrocchio assigned Leonardo the addition of one of the angels in his 'Battesimo di Cristo' ('Baptism of Christ'). So far superior was Leonardo's portion of the painting that Verrocchio is said to have exclaimed, 'the student has surpassed the master!' – and to have given up painting from that day on. The 'Battesimo di Cristo' now hangs in the Galleria degli Uffizi in Florence. The Baptism of Christ (Verrocchio and Leonardo) - Wikipedia

This usually goes along with the teacher aging and perhaps declining in capability.
